articles.author: ALANNA DURKIN RICHER and ERIC TUCKER
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — A federal appeals court in Washington on Friday upheld a gag order on former President Donald Trump in his 2020 election interference case but narrowed the restrictions on his speech.
articles.title: Appeals court upholds gag order on Trump in Washington case but narrows restrictions on his speech

articles.author: WAFAA SHURAFA, JULIA FRANKEL and LEE KEATH
articles.description: DEIR AL-BALAH, Gaza Strip (AP) — Israel said Friday that the military was rounding up Palestinian men in northern Gaza for interrogation, searching for Hamas militants, while desperate Palestinians in the south crowded into an ever-shrinking area, and the U.N.
articles.title: Israeli troops round up Palestinian men in northern Gaza as UN warns aid operation is 'in tatters'

articles.author: ALANNA DURKIN RICHER and ERIC TUCKER
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — A federal appeals court in Washington on Friday upheld a gag order on former President Donald Trump in his 2020 election interference case but narrowed the restrictions on his speech.
articles.title: Appeals court upholds gag order on Trump in Washington case but narrows restrictions on his speech

articles.author: JIM HEINTZ
articles.description: Vladimir Putin on Friday moved to prolong his repressive and unyielding grip on Russia for at least another six years, announcing his candidacy in the presidential election next March that he is all but certain to win.
articles.title: Putin will seek another term as Russian president, aiming to extend his rule of over two decades

articles.author: MICHAEL R. SISAK and MICHAEL BALSAMO
articles.description: Derek Chauvin was stabbed nearly two dozen times in the law library at a federal prison in Arizona.
articles.title: High-profile attacks on Derek Chauvin and Larry Nassar put spotlight on violence in federal prisons

articles.author: MIKE SCHNEIDER
articles.description: The U.S. Census Bureau wants to change how it asks people about disabilities, and some advocates are complaining that they were not consulted enough on what amounts to a major overhaul in how disabilities would be defined by the federal government.
articles.title: The Census Bureau wants to change how it asks about disabilities. Some advocates don't like it

articles.author: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — U.S. employers added a healthy 199,000 jobs last month and the unemployment rate fell, fresh signs that the economy could achieve an elusive “soft landing,” in which inflation would return to the Federal Reserve’s 2% target without causing a steep recession.
articles.title: Solid US hiring lowers unemployment rate in latest sign of a still-sturdy job market

articles.author: COLLIN BINKLEY and MARC LEVY
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — Harvard University's president apologized as pressure mounted for the University of Pennsylvania's president to resign over their testimony at a congressional hearing on antisemitism that critics from the White House on down say failed to show that they would stand up to antisemitism on campus.
articles.title: Harvard president apologizes for remarks on antisemitism as pressure mounts on Penn's president

articles.description: ROME (AP) — Pope Francis on Friday made his first public appearance outdoors since being stricken by bronchitis two weeks ago, which forced him to cancel a planned trip to the COP-28 climate conference in Dubai.
articles.title: Pope Francis makes his first public appearances since being stricken by bronchitis

articles.author: LAURA UNGAR
articles.description: Regulators on Friday approved two gene therapies for sickle cell disease that doctors hope can cure the painful, inherited blood disorder that afflicts mostly Black people in the U.S. The Food and Drug Administration said the one-time treatments can be used for patients 12 and older with severe forms of the disease.
articles.title: Two gene therapies for sickle cell disease approved in US
